sections.heading: SECTION 1 — PURPOSE OF LIGHTING MODELING
sections.content:
1.1 Purpose This manual defines the engineering logic and mathematical methods required to model lighting energy use, lighting retrofit savings, lighting controls impacts, HVAC-lumens interactions, ballast behavior, fixture mapping, and end-use interactions. It provides rules for how AI must identify baseline lighting loads, predict retrofit savings, and produce consistent financial outcomes based on lighting improvements.

1.2 What Lighting Modeling Supports ESCO-grade project scoping Retrofit package creation Lighting audit estimation Lighting-to-HVAC interaction modeling Daylighting synergy Controls evaluation Financial savings and incentive evaluation Multimeasure stacking with battery, HVAC, and controls Lighting schedules inference Interior + exterior lighting identification

1.3 AI Behavior Requirements AI must: Never hallucinate fixture types or wattage Request missing fixture counts or area sizes when critical Follow deterministic engineering relationships Respect ballast behavior Prevent unrealistic savings (>75% whole-facility unless proven) Apply HVAC interaction adjustments correctly Use climate zone guidance for lighting-HVAC coupling Be conservative when hours-of-operation uncertain Explain all reasoning in text

------------------------------------------------------------

sections.heading: SECTION 2 — LIGHTING SYSTEM TYPES AND IDENTIFICATION
sections.content:
------------------------------------------------------------

2.1 Interior Lighting System Types Fluorescent T5, T8, T12 CFL LED tubes (ballast-bypass, ballast-compatible) LED retrofit kits LED panel lights Metal halide high bay High-pressure sodium Incandescent Halogen Decorative luminaires Track lights Downlights

2.2 Exterior Lighting System Types Parking lot pole lights Wallpacks Floodlights Bollards Streetlights Canopy fixtures Area LEDs

2.3 How AI Identifies Lighting Types

Based on: Building type (office → troffers, warehouse → high bay, parking lot → HID) Square footage Ceiling height Lighting density per ASHRAE Historical internal EverWatt project database Fixture counts if provided Interval load “overnight spikes” (indicating exterior lighting) Photo evidence if available

AI must never: Assume LED by default Ignore exterior lighting Apply indoor hours to outdoor loads Confuse HID with LED retrofits

2.4 Mapping Lighting Technologies to Wattages

AI must use realistic baseline wattages:

Troffers: T12: 96W T8: 68W T5HO: 54W LED panel: 30–40W

High bay: Metal halide: 400W–1000W HPS: 250–400W LED high bay: 150–300W

Exterior pole lights: HID: 250–400W typical LED retrofit: 70–150W

Downlights: CFL: 26–42W LED: 12–18W

AI must apply correct fixture-to-watt conversions.

------------------------------------------------------------

sections.heading: SECTION 3 — HOURS OF OPERATION MODELING
sections.content:
------------------------------------------------------------

3.1 Hours of Operation (HOO) Hours greatly affect savings. AI must estimate HOO when not provided using building type:

Office interior: 50–70 hours/week School interior: 40–60 hours/week Hospital: 24/7 for critical areas Warehouse: 2-shift or 3-shift depending on operation Retail interiors: 70–100 hours/week Exterior lights: dusk-to-dawn (~4,000–4,500 hours/year)

3.2 Inferring Hours from Interval Data AI must detect lighting baseload in interval data: If nighttime usage > daytime-off usage → exterior load If early morning spikes with occupancy → interior lights If flat baseload at night → mixed HVAC/lighting if warehouse or industrial

3.3 Schedule-Based Hours If schedule known: HOO = occupied_hours × lighting_profile_factor

3.4 Conservatism Rules If hours uncertain, AI must assume lower hours to avoid overstated savings. AI must not assume 4,000 hours/year for interiors unless specified.

------------------------------------------------------------

sections.heading: SECTION 4 — LIGHTING ENERGY MODELING
sections.content:
------------------------------------------------------------

4.1 Basic Lighting Energy Equation LightingEnergy = FixturePower × Hours × FixtureCount

Where FixturePower = input watts including ballast losses.

4.2 Ballast Factor Fluorescent wattages vary with ballast. Actual fluorescent power = NominalWattage × BallastFactor BallastFactor = 0.77–1.18 depending on ballast type.

AI must adjust fluorescent wattage accordingly.

4.3 LED Driver Power LED wattage includes: LED electrical load Driver conversion loss Thermal losses

AI must assume typical LED driver efficiency = 85–90%.

4.4 Fixture Efficacy Efficacy = lumens per watt AI may use efficacy ratios to determine lumen equivalence but must not mix lumen modeling with energy modeling unless doing daylighting analysis.

4.5 Interactive Effects (HVAC Impact) Lighting produces heat. Reducing lighting reduces cooling load but increases heating load in some climates.

CoolingInteractionSavings (kWh) = LightingEnergyReduction × CoolingFraction × HVAC_COP_Adjustment

HeatingInteractionPenalty (therms) = LightingEnergyReduction × HeatingFraction / BoilerEfficiency

AI must estimate cooling and heating fractions based on climate zone and building type.

4.6 Whole-Building Savings AI must apply interactive adjustment:

NetElectricSavings = LightingSavings_kWh − HeatingPenalty_kWh_equivalent

CoolingReduction_kWh

NetThermSavings = LightingThermPenaltyReduction

RULE: Lighting retrofit always reduces kWh Heating therms may increase depending on climate

------------------------------------------------------------

sections.heading: SECTION 5 — LIGHTING RETROFIT MEASURE MODELING
sections.content:
------------------------------------------------------------

5.1 LED Tube Retrofits (TLEDs) Types: Ballast-compatible Ballast-bypass Hybrid

Savings_TLED = LightingEnergy_old − LightingEnergy_new ± HVAC interactions

AI must verify ballast factor and driver type.

5.2 LED Panel Retrofits PanelWattage ≈ 30–45W Replaces 2x4 fluorescent troffer (68–96W)

Savings_Panel = (OldW − NewW) × HOO × Count Adjusted for HVAC interactions.

5.3 High Bay LED Retrofits HID_to_LED savings substantial: 400W MH → 150W LED 1000W MH → 300W LED

AI must enforce: High bay LED cooling interaction is high in climate zones with cooling dominance.

5.4 Exterior Lighting Retrofits Exterior hours typically 4,200–4,500 hr/yr. Savings significant: 250W HID → 70W LED 400W HID → 120–150W LED

Exterior lights have no HVAC interactions.

5.5 Specialty Lighting Retrofits Track lighting Decorative/museum lighting Halogen spotlights

AI must adjust wattages using fixture libraries.

------------------------------------------------------------

sections.heading: SECTION 6 — CONTROLS MODELING
sections.content:
------------------------------------------------------------

6.1 Occupancy Sensors Savings_Occ = FractionTimeVacant × LightingEnergy_old

Typical values: 20–40% savings in intermittently occupied spaces.

AI must ensure occupancy profiles match building type.

6.2 Daylight Harvesting Savings_Daylight = DaylightZoneFraction × LightingEnergy × DaylightEffectiveness

Where: DaylightZoneFraction = area within 15–20 ft of windows DaylightEffectiveness = 20–60% depending on glazing

6.3 Timeclock Scheduling Savings_Sched = IncorrectlyScheduledHours × FixturePower × Count

AI must detect after-hours usage from interval data patterns.

6.4 High-End Trim High-end trim reduces maximum lighting output. Savings_Trim = ReductionFraction × LightingEnergy

High-end trim ranges from 10–30%.

6.5 Luminaire-Level Lighting Controls (LLLC) LLLC combines occupancy, daylight, high-end trim. Typical savings: 35–60%.

AI must not exceed 60% controls savings even under ideal conditions.

------------------------------------------------------------

sections.heading: SECTION 7 — LIGHTING EFFICIENCY MEASURE BUNDLING
sections.content:
------------------------------------------------------------

7.1 Bundling Rules Bundling lighting retrofits with controls amplifies savings. However, savings must follow proper order:

Lighting retrofit reduces base load. Controls savings must be applied to post-retrofit load, not baseline. HVAC adjustments apply after lighting reduction. Interactive heating penalties must be applied last.

TotalSavings = LightingRetrofitSavings

ControlsSavings(onNewLoad)

CoolingInteractionSavings − HeatingPenalty

7.2 Exterior + Interior Bundling Exterior savings unaffected by interior hours. Interior + exterior must be summed.

7.3 Multi-Floor Building Bundling Basements may have low hours; AI must vary HOO by area.

------------------------------------------------------------

sections.heading: SECTION 8 — LIGHTING INCENTIVES & PROGRAM RULES
sections.content:
------------------------------------------------------------

8.1 Incentive Structures Incentives may be: Per fixture Per kWh saved Per watt reduced Per square foot Custom calculated (measurement and verification)

AI must determine which applies.

8.2 DLC Premium Requirement Most utilities require DLC-listed or ENERGY STAR-rated fixtures.

AI must check LED fixture eligibility.

8.3 Incentive Caps Utilities may cap: Max 50% of project cost Max $0.50 to $1.00 per sq ft Fixture count limits

AI must enforce caps.

8.4 Interactive Effects on Incentives Some utilities DO NOT incentivize HVAC interactive benefits. AI must separate direct lighting energy savings from HVAC interactions.

------------------------------------------------------------

sections.heading: SECTION 9 — LIGHTING CLIMATE ZONE ADJUSTMENT
sections.content:
------------------------------------------------------------

9.1 Cooling-Dominant Climates Reduce HVAC cooling load by: CoolingInteractionSavings ~ 10–20% of lighting savings

Heating penalty is small.

9.2 Heating-Dominant Climates Minimal cooling interaction Heating penalty significant: HeatingPenalty = LightingReduction × HeatingFraction

AI must apply penalty.

9.3 Mild Climates Both cooling and heating interactions exist but moderate.

AI must apply balanced adjustment.

------------------------------------------------------------

sections.heading: SECTION 10 — REAL-WORLD EXAMPLES
sections.content:
------------------------------------------------------------

10.1 Office Example Fluorescent troffers → LED panels Baseline: 68W New: 38W Hours: 60/week HVAC cooling interaction: +8% savings Heating penalty: small in CZ3

10.2 Warehouse Example Metal halide → high bay LED Baseline: 400W New: 150W Hours: 2 shifts HVAC interaction minimal

10.3 School Example Mixed RTU system Lighting + occupancy sensors Hours: 1800–2000 per year HVAC heating penalty minimal

10.4 Hospital Example 24/7 areas Reduction in lighting reduces cooling load Large HVAC interaction

------------------------------------------------------------

sections.heading: SECTION 11 — VALIDATION MATRIX
sections.content:
------------------------------------------------------------

11.1 Validation Rules

Test 1 — Wattage Reasonableness If LED wattage < 10W for high bay → fail If HID baseline wattage < 200W for pole light → fail

Test 2 — Hours Reasonableness If interior hours > 6000 → fail If exterior hours < 2500 → fail

Test 3 — Interactive Effects If interactive cooling savings > 30% lighting → fail If heating penalty ignored in cold climate → fail

Test 4 — Controls Savings If occupancy savings > 60% of post-retrofit → fail If daylight harvesting > 70% → fail

Test 5 — Total Savings If whole building lighting savings > 60% → flag for review Unless replacing HID-heavy facility

11.2 AI Response to Failures AI must: Reject savings Ask for more inputs Reduce assumptions Provide conservative estimates

------------------------------------------------------------

sections.heading: SECTION 12 — IMPLEMENTATION RULES FOR AI
sections.content:
------------------------------------------------------------

12.1 Required Inputs Fixture type Wattage Hours Fixture count Climate zone Building type

12.2 Modeling Process 1 Identify fixture types 2 Determine hours 3 Compute baseline energy 4 Compute retrofit energy 5 Apply controls 6 Apply HVAC interactions 7 Apply incentives 8 Compute total savings

12.3 IAQ and Safety Constraints AI must check: Minimum lighting levels Egress lighting Exterior safety lighting Code restrictions

12.4 Output Requirements AI must produce: kWh saved Therms saved or added Lighting wattage reduction HVAC interaction adjustments Incentive estimation Payback, NPV, IRR Confidence level
